summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with the Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 12, 2019. The interview focuses on the handling, housing, and suicide watch protocols for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, the events surrounding his suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, his subsequent placement and cellmate assignment, and the circumstances leading to his death on August 9-10, 2019. The Warden discusses staffing issues, camera reliability, and internal communications.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: High-profile inmate at MCC New York who died by suicide. The interview details his arrival, placement in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), a prior suicide attempt, his cellmate assignment, and the discovery of his body.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Inmate who was initially considered as a cellmate for Epstein and was present during Epstein's first suicide attempt in July. He reported thinking Epstein was having a heart attack.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: Older inmate who was ultimately selected as Epstein's cellmate after being vetted from a shortlist. He was released from MCC on the morning of August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Employee whose primary duty is in the warehouse/commissary but who was working overtime as a Correctional Officer in the SHU on the night of Epstein's death. He was the first to discover Epstein and initiated life-saving measures.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: Correctional Officer assigned to the SHU who was on duty the night of Epstein's death. She spoke to the Warden by phone during the incident.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: The Operations Lieutenant on duty who responded to the incident, performed life-saving measures on Epstein, and later provided a memorandum about staff statements regarding missed counts.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: The Captain at MCC. The Warden stated he gave this Captain direct orders that Epstein was to have a cellmate at all times and that the Captain confirmed he disseminated these orders.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.context: The Associate Warden who was acting Warden while the Warden was on leave during Epstein's first suicide attempt in July. She notified the Warden and the region of the incident.

persons.name: Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The Chief Psychologist at MCC who oversaw Epstein's mental health evaluation and the decision to remove him from suicide watch. She discussed Epstein's status in weekly SHU meetings.

persons.name: Regional Director
persons.context: The Warden's direct supervisor who gave the initial order to keep Epstein in the SHU and not place him in general population. The Warden notified him of key events, including the suicide attempt and Epstein's death.

connections.description: The Warden was responsible for Epstein's overall custody and housing at MCC. He had brief interactions with Epstein and was briefed on all aspects of his confinement.
Reyes was vetted and assigned to be Epstein's cellmate in the SHU after Epstein was taken off suicide watch. Reyes was released on the morning of Epstein's death.
Tartaglione was Epstein's cellmate during a prior incident in July that was investigated as a possible suicide attempt.
The Warden reported directly to the Regional Director and consulted with him on major decisions regarding Epstein's housing and notified him of critical incidents.
The Warden gave the Captain specific verbal orders that Epstein was to have a cellmate at all times and followed up to ensure the orders were disseminated.
The Chief Psychologist and her department were responsible for Epstein's mental health evaluations, placing him on and removing him from suicide watch, and discussing his status in meetings.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt / Incident
events.description: An incident occurred in Epstein's cell with cellmate Tartaglione that was investigated as a possible suicide attempt. Epstein was placed on suicide watch following protocols.

events.title: Epstein Downgraded to Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was moved from suicide watch to psychological observation (a less restrictive status) on the second-floor medical unit.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU with Cellmate
events.description: Epstein was moved back to the Special Housing Unit from psychological observation. The Warden selected inmate Reyes as his cellmate after vetting a shortlist.

events.title: Reyes Released from MCC
events.description: Inmate Reyes was discharged from MCC "with all belongings," leaving Epstein without a cellmate. Staff packing his belongings did not notify superiors that Epstein needed a new cellmate.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Body
events.description: Around 6:45-6:50 PM, Correctional Officer Michael Thomas discovered Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive in his cell. Thomas called for medical emergency and began life-saving measures. Epstein was pronounced dead at an outside hospital.

events.title: OIG Interview of MCC Warden
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with the Warden of MCC regarding the handling of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Second-floor medical/suicide watch unit at MCC
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC unexpectedly on a weekend without formal notification to the Warden, and was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on the following Monday.
The BOP Northeast Regional Director ordered that Epstein be kept in the SHU and not placed in general population.
After a prior incident on July 23, Epstein was placed on suicide watch, then downgraded to psychological observation, and finally returned to the SHU with a cellmate (Reyes) on July 30.

Epstein's cellmate, Reyes, was discharged from MCC on the morning of August 9, 2019. Staff who packed his belongings failed to notify superiors that Epstein was left without a cellmate, contrary to specific orders.

The Warden stated the MCC was understaffed (around 80%), cameras were unreliable and outdated, and staff often worked significant overtime, including personnel from other departments like Michael Thomas.
